title: Trump Is Right-the Fed Is Still Tightening
summary: Sure, the size of the balance sheet is holding steady, but leaving riskier assets in the market will slow growth.. It must be annoying for Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell when President Trump berates him on Twitter -especially when Mr. Trump insists he take policy steps he's already taken. This seemed to happen last week when the president tweeted that the Fed must "stop their ridiculous quantitative tightening NOW!" Huh? At the Federal Open Market Committee's meeting two weeks ago, Mr. Powell and his colleagues announced the immediate halt of the shrinking of its asset portfolio, two months earlier than expected. It has now stabilized at about $3.6 trillion.

title: China Is No Manipulator
summary: We cannot on one hand condemn China for manipulating currency and then turn around and do the same.. We cannot on one hand condemn China for manipulating currency and then turn around and do the same. It would be a complete loss of global credibility, not to say hypocritical. It would make a mockery of free-market principles that the U.S. has a responsibility to protect, defend and enforce.

title: California Curriculum Proposal Is in Process
summary: California is developing an Ethnic Studies Model Curriculum in response to a 2016 state law. Evers notes in "California Wants to Teach Your Kids That Capitalism Is Racist" (op-ed, July 30), California is developing an Ethnic Studies Model Curriculum in response to a 2016 state law requiring the state to create an optional guide for high schools interested in offering such courses. The draft recently posted, which Mr. Evers critiqued as if it was already adopted, is many months away from coming to the state board for review or approval. Written by an advisory committee to the Instructional Quality Commission (IQC), this early draft will be analyzed and substantially revised several times over before it makes its way to the state board next year.

title: Just How Important Is a Presidential Candidate's Hair?
summary: Donald Trump's comb-over has become the President's sartorial signature. Can any of the democratic presidential candidates compete when it comes to memorable hairdos?. AFTER LAST MONTH'S two Democratic primary presidential debates, one thing was certain: Never before in the history of political campaigns have we seen such a diverse array of...hair styles. Compared to the straightforward, crisply combed styles that Republican candidates typically sported in 2016, the coifs of the 20 Democrats on stage ran the full gamut: from Cory Booker's cue-ball dome to Joe Biden's shock-white mop to Tulsi Gabbard's gray streak. At this early stage, with an array of candidates that rivals the number of toilet-paper rolls in a big-box value pack, hair is one of the few things that voters may actually remember. "[Hair] is part of a candidate's appearance and presence," one of the standard ways we size people up, said Peter Loge, an associate professor of political communication at George Washington University.

title: What the AMA Stands For Now
summary: The association's president discusses its lawsuit against North Dakota and its other recent advocacy efforts. Under a new president, Patrice Harris, the American Medical Association made a splash in the reproductive-rights debate in June by suing North Dakota to block two abortion-related laws. One of those laws requires physicians to tell patients that medication-induced abortions can be reversed in some instances, which the suit says is false; the other requires doctors to tell patients that an abortion terminates "the life of a whole, separate, unique living human being."

title: The Downside of Extroverted CEOs
summary: Companies run by charismatic leaders tend to have a higher cost of equity capital. While talkative, energetic, sociable leaders may wow investors and employees, they may not be good for business.

title: How the New York Public Library Guards Privacy in the Digital Age
summary: When it comes to data, 'we keep huge amounts. We just don't keep any data about you.'. The ever-changing digital landscape poses a challenge for libraries: How do they enter this new world-while staying true to their public mission and preserving the privacy of patrons online?

title: For Lyft's CFO, It's Meeting After Meeting After Meeting...
summary: CFO Brian Roberts talks about the value of anything-goes conversations. Over the years, Lyft Inc.'s chief financial officer, Brian Roberts, has come to believe in the magic of open discussions.

title: The Potentially High Cost of Being Friends With the Boss
summary: When the office knows who's getting a bonus, managers favor other employees to avoid the appearance of bias. Friends with the boss? It turns out that might cost you.

title: The Link Between Pay and Job Satisfaction Comes With a Twist
summary: Among companies that pay poorly compared with their peers, job satisfaction is low at companies with the weakest finances-and the strongest finances. It probably doesn't take a management guru to figure out that if you want satisfied employees, it pays to pay them well.
